Award.AwardTitle: Interdisciplinary Antarctic Earth Science Meeting 2019 plus Deep Field Planning Workshop; October 2019; Julian, CA
Award.AbstractNarration:
The award supports the biennial Interdisciplinary Antarctic Earth Sciences Conference (IAES) and the Antarctic Deep Field Camp Planning Workshop. IAES brings together U.S. researchers including biologists, glaciologists, geologists, and atmospheric scientists to present recent findings and data that apply to Antarctic earth sciences questions. IAES promotes a productive, interdisciplinary approach highlighting connections between research topics. IAES provides valuable development for early career scientists. Early career scientists will be invited speakers and members of the organizational committee. The field camp workshop aims at identifying the highest priority questions that are driving Antarctic science and what sectors within the continent are suited best to address the outstanding questions.

The project will provide partial subsistence support for ~ 70 participants. The project support travel costs for up to 20 participants to attend IAES and the Field Camp Planning Workshop. Travel funds are provided for invited speakers and the organizing committee members. IAES is a unique opportunity for Antarctic scientists to present their work address fundamental Antarctic earth science questions from an interdisciplinary perspective. The Deep Field Camp Planning Workshop will deliver a ranking of field sites and scientific questions to be addressed at each site.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported a very successful Interdisciplinary Antarctic Earth Sciences conference and Antarctic Deep Field Camp Planning Workshop held October 13-16 2019 at Camp Cedar Glen near Julian, CA for 65 registered participants. The small format of the conference and workshop makes them uniquely positioned to facilitate interactions between Antarctic researchers in a way that improves awareness, data sharing and cooperation among independent researchers, and in doing so supports a key recommendation by the National Academy to the NSF. A total of 43 oral and poster presentations were given. Representatives of major science support centers presented updates about research and planning resources (Polar Rock Repository, OSU Marine & Geology Repository, and the Polar Geospatial Center). Dr. Gale Sinatra led a workshop titled 'Public Understanding of Science: Challenges and Opportunities for Science Communication' for all conference participants to help scientists more effectively communicate the broader impact of their work. A mentoring event was held so that early career researchers could have dedicated time to talk with established scientists willing to offer career guidance and support. The organizing committee deliberately sought out early career researchers for Invited talks to elevate their visibility within the research community.

Prior to the Antarctic Deep Field Camp Planning Workshop, a survey was sent to the U.S. Antarctic Earth Sciences research community to gather preliminary data on interest in potential future camp locations. Almost 90 researchers responded, and results revealed N. Victoria Land and Scott Glacier as the top 'first choice' picks for the next camp. At the workshop a select group of scientists summarized the setting and research opportunities at each of the 5 sites under discussion (N. Victoria Land, Scott Glacier, Ellsworth Mountains, Marie Byrd Land and James Ross & Seymour Islands). Additionally, the scientific community was invited to submit expressions of their research interests including significance of potential projects at the 5 deep field camp sites. Over 25 posters were submitted representing groups of researchers likely to collaborate. The ensuing thoughtful deliberations resulted in consensus ratings of how well each potential field camp site could address the higest-priorty research themes. The highest rating was for a camp located in N. Victoria Land, closely followed by one at Scott Glacier, similar to the initial community survey results.
